When you are practicing giving, you should think like this:
The giving that I cultivate is universally given to all sentient beings, and we together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
When you are upholding precepts, you should think like this:
The pure precepts that I cultivate are universally given to all sentient beings, and we together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
When you are practicing patience, you should think like this:
The patience you cultivate, give it to all sentient beings, and together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
When you are practicing diligence, you should think like this:
The diligence I cultivate, give it to all sentient beings, and together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
When you are practicing concentration, you should think like this:
The concentration I cultivate, give it to all sentient beings, and together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
When you are practicing wisdom, you should think like this:
The wisdom I cultivate, give it to all sentient beings, and together dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with form, nor should you take it with feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.
Why is it so?
If one does not grasp form, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the eye-base, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, or mind-base.
Why is it so?
If one does not grasp the eye-base, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, or mind-base, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the form-base, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the sound-, smell-, taste-, touch-, or dharma-base.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the sense field of form, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the sense fields of sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the eye element, nor should you grasp it with the form element, eye consciousness element, eye contact, or the feelings produced by eye contact as a condition.
Why is this?

If one does not grasp the eye element, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the form element up to the feelings produced by eye contact as a condition, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the ear element, nor should you grasp it with the sound element, ear consciousness element, ear contact, or the feelings produced by ear contact as a condition.
Why is this?

If one does not grasp the ear-sphere, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the sound-sphere, up to the ear-contact as a condition, the various feelings that arise, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the nose-sphere, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the smell-sphere, nose-consciousness-sphere, and nose-contact as a condition, the various feelings that arise.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the nose-sphere, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the smell-sphere, up to the nose-contact as a condition, the various feelings that arise, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the tongue-sphere, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the taste-sphere, tongue-consciousness-sphere, and tongue-contact as a condition, the various feelings that arise.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the tongue element, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the taste element, up to the tongue contact and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the body element, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the touch element, the body consciousness element, body contact, or the feelings produced from the condition of body contact.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the body element, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the touch element, up to body contact and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the mind element, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the dharma element, the mind consciousness element, mind contact, or the feelings produced from the condition of mind contact.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the mind-sphere, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the dharma-sphere up to the mental contact-conditioned feelings, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the earth element, nor should you grasp it with the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the earth element, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with ignorance, nor should you grasp it with the formative factors, consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, depression, and anguish.

If one does not grasp ignorance, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the formations up to old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through the perfection of giving, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through the perfection of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, or wisdom.

If one does not grasp the perfection of giving, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with internal emptiness, nor should you take it with external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, empty emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, endless emptiness, dispersed emptiness, unchanging emptiness, inherent emptiness, specific emptiness, common emptiness, all dharmas emptiness, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, or emptiness of the nature of non-existence of self-nature.

Because if one does not take internal emptiness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of non-existence of self-nature, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by taking true suchness, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by taking the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, birthlessness nature, dharma determination, dharma abode, reality limit, space realm, or inconceivable realm.
Why is it so?

Because if one does not take true suchness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by taking the noble truth of suffering, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by taking the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path.
Why is it so?

Because if one does not take the noble truth of suffering, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

Because if one does not take the four meditations, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless concentrations, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the eight liberations, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the eight superior realms, the nine successive concentrations, or the ten universal bases.

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the four establishments of mindfulness, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, or eightfold noble path.

Because if one does not take the four establishments of mindfulness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the four right efforts up to the eightfold noble path, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the door of liberation of emptiness, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the door of liberation of signlessness or wishlessness.

Because if one does not take the door of liberation of emptiness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the door of liberation of signlessness or wishlessness, one attains unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the ten grounds of the bodhisattva.
Why is it so?
If one does not take the ten grounds of the bodhisattva, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
'Good son!
You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the five eyes, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the six supernormal knowledges.
Why is it so?
If one does not take the five eyes, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, and if one does not take the six supernormal knowledges, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
'Good son!

You should not take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the ten powers of the Buddha, nor should you take unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.
Why is it so?

If one does not grasp the ten powers of a buddha, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the four forms of fearlessness, up to the eighteen distinctive qualities unique to a buddha, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the dharma of non-forgetfulness, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the nature of always abiding in abandonment.

If one does not grasp the dharma of non-forgetfulness, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp the nature of always abiding in abandonment, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

You should not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with omniscience, nor should you grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment with the cognition of the attributes of the path, or with the cognition of all aspects.

If one does not grasp for omniscience, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If one does not grasp for the cognition of the aspects of the path and the cognition of all aspects, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not grasp for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, nor should you grasp for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through all samÄdhi gateways.

You should not grasp for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through the fruit of stream-entry, nor should you grasp for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment through the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, or the fruit of arhatship.

If one does not attain the fruit of stream-entry, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment; if one does not attain the fruit of once-returning, non-returning, or arhatship, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good son!
You should not attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the enlightenment of a pratyekabuddha.

You should not attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the practices of all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.

If one does not attain the practices of all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, one will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

You should not attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by means of the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of all buddhas.
Why is it so?
If one does not grasp unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, one can attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards form, nor give rise to craving and attachment towards feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness.
Why is this?
Because form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are not to be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good man!
Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the eye sense base, nor give rise to craving and attachment towards the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind sense bases.
Why is this?
Because the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are not to be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good man!

You should not give rise to craving and attachment towards the sense-field of form, nor should you give rise to craving and attachment towards the sense-fields of sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
Why is this?
Because the sense-fields of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas are not to be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good son!

You should not give rise to craving and attachment towards the eye-element, nor should you give rise to craving and attachment towards the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, eye-contact, or the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as a condition.

Because the eye-element up to the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as a condition are not to be craved or attached to.

You should not give rise to craving and attachment towards the ear-element, nor should you give rise to craving and attachment towards the sound-element, ear-consciousness-element, ear-contact, or the various feelings that arise from ear-contact as a condition.

Because the ear-element up to the ear-contact as a condition for the arising of the various feelings are not to be greedily attached to.

Because the nose-element up to the nose-contact as a condition for the arising of the various feelings are not to be greedily attached to.

Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the mind element, nor towards the dharma element, the mind consciousness element, mind contact, or the various feelings produced with mind contact as their condition.

Because the mind element up to the various feelings produced with mind contact as their condition are not to be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.

You should not give rise to craving and attachment towards the earth element, nor towards the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements.
Why is this?
Because the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements are not to be craved or attached to.

You should not give rise to craving and attachment towards ignorance, nor towards the formative factors, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.
Why is this?
Because ignorance up to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress are not to be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good son!
You should not have craving and attachment towards the perfection of generosity, nor towards the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, concentration, or wisdom.

Because generosity up to the perfection of wisdom cannot be craved or attached to.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good son!

You should not have craving and attachment towards internal emptiness, nor towards external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of inherent existence, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of general characteristics, emptiness of all dharmas, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature of non-existence, or emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence.

You should not give rise to greed and attachment towards suchness, nor should you give rise to greed and attachment towards the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, detached nature, dharma determination, dharma abiding, reality limit, space realm, or inconceivable realm.

Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the four dhyÄnas, nor give rise to craving and attachment towards the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations.

Good sons!

Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the eight liberations, nor give rise to craving and attachment towards the eight superior [spheres of] perception, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases.

Because the eight liberations, eight superior [spheres of] perception, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases are not to be craved or attached to.

Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is emptiness.

You should not give rise to craving for the four establishments of mindfulness, nor should you give rise to craving for the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, or eightfold noble path.

Because the four establishments of mindfulness up to the eightfold noble path are not to be craved for.

Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.
Good son!
You should not give rise to craving for the door of liberation of emptiness, nor should you give rise to craving for the door of liberation of signlessness or wishlessness.

Good son!
You should not give rise to craving for the ten grounds of the bodhisattva.

Because the ten grounds of the bodhisattva are not to be craved for.

Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is emptiness.
Good sons!
Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the five eyes, and do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the six supernormal powers.

Because the five eyes and six supernormal powers are not to be craved or attached to.

Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is emptiness.

Do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the ten powers of the Buddha, and do not give rise to craving and attachment towards the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.

Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is emptiness.
Good sons!

It is because the Dharma of non-forgetfulness and the nature of constant abandonment are not to be greedily loved.

Good son!
You should not give rise to greed and love towards omniscience, nor should you give rise to greed and love towards the cognition of the characteristics of the path and the cognition of all aspects.
Why is it so?
It is because omniscience, the cognition of the characteristics of the path, and the cognition of all aspects are not to be greedily loved.

It is because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is empty.

Do not give rise to craving for the fruit of stream-entry, nor for the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, or the fruit of arhatship.

Because the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship are not to be craved for.

For the sake of sentient beings, proclaim and reveal that form is neither a destination nor not a destination.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of form is empty, and in emptiness there is no destination and no non-destination.
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also neither a destination nor not a destination.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness is empty, and in emptiness there is no destination and no non-destination.
